sen.j: 源 行家（みなもと の ゆきいえ）は、平安時代末期の武将。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yukiie was the busho (Japanese military commander) of the end of Heian Period.
MINAMOTO no Yukiie was a military commander (busho) during the later part of the Heian Period.
MINAMOTO no Yukiie was a military commander (busho) during the later part of the Heian Period.

sen.j: 河内源氏第五代源為義の十男。
sen.e: He was the tenth son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi of Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan).
He was the tenth son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi of the Kawachi-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan.
He was the tenth son of MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi of the Kawachi-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan.

sen.j: 初めの名乗りを義盛という。
sen.e: He was first called as Yoshimori.
At first he went by the name Yoshimori.
At first he went by the name Yoshimori.

sen.j: 新宮十郎、新宮行家とも。
sen.e: He was also called as Juro and Yukiie SHINGU.
He was also called Juro and Yukiie SHINGU.
He was also called Juro and Yukiie SHINGU.

sen.j: 以仁王の挙兵に伴い、諸国の源氏に以仁王令旨を伝え歩き、平氏打倒の決起を促した。
sen.e: He followed the Rising of Prince Mochihito and travelled to Minamoto Clan of different provinces, delivering the message of ryoji (orders issued by princes, empresses, and those of similar ranking) of Prince Mochihito and rallied for the conquest of Taira Clan.

He took part in the uprising led by Prince Mochihito, and travelled to stronholds of the Minamoto Clan in different provinces, conveying communiques and orders from Prince Mochihito, and rallied for the subjugation of the Taira Clan.

He took part in the uprising led by Prince Mochihito, and travelled to strongholds of the Minamoto Clan in different provinces, conveying communiques and orders from Prince Mochihito, and rallied for the subjugation of the Taira Clan.

sen.j: 熊野三山の要職に就いていた新宮別当家嫡流の行範（のちに19代熊野別当に就任）の妻となった鳥居禅尼（たつたはらの女房）の異母弟として生まれ、しばらく熊野速玉大社に住んでいたため新宮十郎と称した。
sen.e: He was born as the paternal younger brother of Torii Zenni, who was the wife of Yukinori, who was assigned with valuable position of Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano Hongu Taisha, Kumano Hayatama Taisha and Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrines) and the main branch of the Shingu betto (Chief officer serving Shingu) family, and lived in Kumano Hayatama Taisha that he was called as Shingu Juro.

He was born the younger half-brother (to a different mother) of Torii Zenni, who later became the wife of Yukinori of the branch of the Shingu betto family who had held important positions as the main administrators of the three major shrines of Kumano (the Kumano Sanzan, including the Kumano Hongu Taisha, Kumano Hayatama Taisha, and Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrines) and later became Chief Officer (betto) serving the main branch of the Shingu family; becauase he lived in Kumano Hayatama Taisha Shrine, he was called Shingu Juro.
sen.cmt: somewhat unclear Japanese, 新宮別当家嫡流?? たつたはらの女房??
sen.e: He was born the younger half-brother (to a different mother) of Torii Zenni (also known as Tatsutanoharano Nyobo before becoming a Buddhist nun), who was the wife of Yukinori of the branch of the Shingu betto family who had held important positions as the main administrators of the three major shrines of Kumano (the Kumano Sanzan, including the Kumano Hongu Taisha, Kumano Hayatama Taisha, and Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrines) and later became the 19th Chief Officer (betto) serving the main branch of the Shingu family; because he lived in Kumano Hayatama Taisha Shrine, he was called Juro SHINGU.
sen.cmt: (also known as Tatsutanoharano Nyobo before becoming a Buddhist nun)説明補足。later became→wasShingu Juro→Juro SHINGUスペルを修正

sen.j: 平治元年（1159年）平治の乱では兄・源義朝に味方して従軍。
sen.e: He was sided his older brother, MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo and supported his army during the Heiji no Ran (Heiji Rebellion) in 1159.
He was the side of his older brother, MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo in fighting that occurred during the Heiji no Ran (Heiji Rebellion) in 1159.
He was the ally of his older brother MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo during the Heiji Rebellion in 1159.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 戦闘には敗れるが、戦線離脱に成功して熊野に逃れ、その後約20年間、同地に雌伏する。
sen.e: He lost in the battle but managed to escape from the front lines to Kumano and laid low in the same area for the later twenty years.
Althought they were defeated in battle, he managed to escape from the front lines to Kumano, where he laid low for the following twenty years.
Although they were defeated in battle, he managed to escape from the front lines to Kumano, where he laid low for the following twenty years.

sen.j: 治承4年（1180年）、摂津源氏の源頼政に召し出され以仁王の平家追討の令旨を各地の源氏に伝達した。
sen.e: He was invited by MINAMOTO no Yorimasa of Settsu Genji (Minamoto Clan in Settsu Province) in 1180 and acted as a messenger of the order of Prince Mochihito to subjugate Taira Clan to Minamoto Clan of various areas.

In 1180, he was summoned by MINAMOTO no Yorimasa of the Settsu-Genji branch of the Minamoto Clan to act as a messenger conveying to the Minamoto Clan in each Province the orders of Prince Mochihito to subjugate Taira Clan.

In 1180, he was summoned by MINAMOTO no Yorimasa of the Settsu-Genji branch of the Minamoto Clan to act as a messenger conveying to the Minamoto Clan in each Province the orders of Prince Mochihito to subjugate Taira Clan.

sen.j: 八条院の蔵人に補され、行家と改名したのはこの時である。
sen.e: He was assigned to be the Kurodo (Chamberlain) of Hojo-in and it was at this time that he changed his name to Yukiie.
He was assigned to be the Chamberlain (Kurodo) of the Hachijo-in, and it was at this time that he changed his name to Yukiie.
He was assigned to be the Chamberlain (Kurodo) of the Hachijo-in, and it was at this time that he changed his name to Yukiie.

sen.j: 甥の源頼朝に決起を促したのも行家であるが、頼朝の麾下には入らず独立勢力を目指したため不和となる。
sen.e: Although it was Yukiie who rallied his nephew, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, he did not subjugate himself under the commands of Yoritomo and led to a quarrel with him for seeking an independent power.

Although it was Yukiie who rallied his nephew, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, to the cause, Yukiie did not place himself under the command of Yoritomo, leading to discord in relation to his aiming to adopt an independent stance.

Although it was Yukiie who rallied his nephew, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, to the cause, Yukiie did not place himself under the command of Yoritomo, leading to discord in relation to his aiming to adopt an independent stance.

sen.j: 養和元年（1181年）、尾張国の墨俣川の戦い、三河国矢作川の戦いで二回に渡り平家方と交戦。
sen.e: He exchanged battles twice with Taira Clan during the Battle of Sunomata River and Yahagi River of Miwa Province in 1181.
He engaged in battle twice against theTaira Clan in 1181, at the Battle of Sunomata River, in Owari Province, and the Battle of Yahagi River, in Miwa Province.
He engaged in battle twice against theTaira Clan in 1181, at the Battle of Sunomata River, in Owari Province, and the Battle of Yahagi River, in Miwa Province.

sen.j: 壊滅的な敗北を喫し、頼朝のもとに逃れた。
sen.e: He was faced with a great defeat and escaped to the place of Yoritomo.
The forces he was fighting on the side of were obliterated, and he escaped to the Yoritomo's stronghold.
The forces he was fighting for were obliterated, and he escaped to the Yoritomo's stronghold.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: さらに、頼朝に所領を求めるも拒否されたため、以降は甥の源義仲の幕下に走った。
sen.e: He demanded to receive the estate from Yoritomo but was denied so he sought the camp of his nephew, MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.
He had sought to stay at the estate of Yoritomo, but was denied, so he took refuge at the camp of his nephew, MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.
He had sought to stay at the estate of Yoritomo, but was denied, so he took refuge at the camp of his nephew, MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.

sen.j: 寿永2年（1183年）義仲とともに入京、後白河天皇の前では義仲と序列を争い、相並んで前後せずに拝謁した。
sen.e: He entered Kyoto with Yoshinaka in 1183 and quarreled concerning the placement of their ranking before the Emperor Goshirakawa, and had an audience with him by lined up side by side, not back and front.

He entered Kyoto with Yoshinaka in 1183, where they quarreled regarding the positions they would assume in light of their respective ranks when they were received by Emperor Goshirakawa; in the end, they decided to stand side-by-side, instead of one in front of the other.

He entered Kyoto with Yoshinaka in 1183, where they quarreled regarding the positions they would assume in light of their respective ranks before Emperor Goshirakawa; in the end, they decided to stand side-by-side, instead of one in front of the other.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 従五位下備後国守に叙任されるが、義仲と差があるとして不満を述べ、すぐに備前国守に遷任する。
sen.e: He was given the Jo rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and the Bingo no kuni no kami (Governor of Bingo Province), but was reassigned to the position of the Governor of Bizen Province after he complained that there was a difference between Yoshinaka and him.

He was awarded the court rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed as Governor of Bingo Province (Bingo no kuni no kami), but was reassigned as Governor of Bizen Province after he complained that there was a discrepancy between his appointment and Yoshinaka's.
sen.cmt: grammar, origin of the "Jo" in first translation is a mytery, inconsistent capitalization
sen.e: He was awarded the court rank of Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade and appointed as Governor of Bingo Province (Bingo no kuni no kami), but was reassigned as Governor of Bizen Province after he complained that there was a discrepancy between his appointment and Yoshinaka's.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 山村育ちで無骨な義仲が法皇や貴族達の不興を買う一方、近畿育ちで弁舌が立つ行家は院内にいりびたり、法皇の双六の相手などをして取り入った。
sen.e: While Yoshinaka, who grew up in a mountain village and had foul mouth lost favor of the cloistered emperor and aristocrats, Yukiie, who was brought up in a Kinki Region (area around Osaka) and had eloquent speech became a constant visitor of the imperial court and played sugoroku (Japanese backgammon) with the retired emperor.

While Yoshinaka, who had grown up in a mountain village and had uncouth mannerisms and language, fell out of favor with the cloistered emperor and aristocrats, Yukiie, who had been brought up in the Kinki Region (the area around Osaka), was cultured and had eloquent mannerism and speech, became a constant visitor of the Imperial Court, often playing Japanese backgammon (sugoroku) with the retired emperor.

While Yoshinaka, who had grown up in a mountain village and had uncouth mannerisms and language, fell out of favor with the cloistered emperor and aristocrats, Yukiie, who had been brought up in the Kinki Region (the area around Osaka), was cultured and had eloquent mannerism and speech, became a constant visitor of the Imperial Court, often playing Japanese backgammon (sugoroku) with the retired emperor.

sen.j: しかしほどなく義仲とも不和となり、身の危険を感じて、平家討伐に名を借りて京を脱出。
sen.e: However, his relation with Yoshinaka worsened, and used an excuse of Taira Clan subjugation to escape from Kyo (Kyoto) after sensing danger for his life.
However, his relation with Yoshinaka worsened, and sensing that he was in danger, he took as an excuse the need to rally the troops to subjugate the Taira Clan to abscond from the capital (Kyoto).
However, his relation with Yoshinaka worsened, and sensing that he was in danger, he fled from the capital (Kyoto) on the pretext of his need to rally the troops to subjugate the Taira Clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 播磨国で平知盛・平重衡軍との室山の戦いでまたしても敗北を喫し、さらに義仲が派遣した樋口兼光にも敗れて行方不明となった。
sen.e: He was defeated again in Suma Province during the Battle of Muroyama against the army of Tomomori and Shigehira TAIRA, and lost against Kanemitsu HIGUCHI dispatched by Yoshinaka before he went missing.

He was defeated again in Suma Province during the Battle of Muroyama against an army led by Tomomori TAIRA and Shigehira TAIRA, and lost against Kanemitsu HIGUCHI, who had been dispatched by Yoshinaka, after which his whereabouts became unknown.

He was defeated again in Suma Province during the Battle of Muroyama against an army led by Tomomori TAIRA and Shigehira TAIRA, and lost against Kanemitsu HIGUCHI, who had been dispatched by Yoshinaka; thereafter, his whereabouts became unknown.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 生来、扇動者としての才と権謀術数に長けてはいたが、軍略面での才能には乏しかったようである。
sen.e: He had a talent as the agitator and Machiavellism but seemed to lack a military skill.
Though he was a capable agent provacateur, and deft at Machiavellian intrigue, he seems to have lacked the ability to develop military strategies.
Though he was a capable agent provocateur, and deft at Machiavellian intrigue, he seems to have lacked the ability to develop military strategies.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 義仲が頼朝の派遣した源範頼・源義経の軍勢に討たれた後、行家は元暦元年（1184年）2月に院の召しによって帰京している。
sen.e: After Yoshinaka fell under the army of MINAMOTO no Noriyori and Yoshitsune dispatched by Yoritomo, Yukiie went back to Kyoto after being invited by the emperor in March 1184.
After Yoshinaka was defeated by the army led by MINAMOTO no Noriyori and Yoshitsune that was dispatched by Yoritomo, Yukiie returned to Kyoto after being invited by the emperor, in March 1184.
After Yoshinaka was defeated by the army led by MINAMOTO no Noriyori and Yoshitsune that was dispatched by Yoritomo, Yukiie returned to Kyoto after being invited by the emperor, in March 1184.

sen.j: その後の鎌倉源氏軍による平氏追討には参加しておらず、甥の義経に接近しながらも鎌倉に参向しようとはせず、半ば独立した立場をとって和泉国と河内国（河内源氏の本拠地）を支配していた。
sen.e: He did not participate in the search and assassination of theTaira Clan by the army of Kamakura-Genji (the Minamoto clan), did not visit Kamakura despite being close to his nephew Yoshitsune, and took an independence stance to rule Izumi and Kawachi Provinces (the headquarter of Kawachi Genji (Minamoto clan in Kawachi Province)).

He did not take part in the campaigns by the army of Kamakura-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan to pursue and subjugate theTaira Clan, and did not visit Kamakura, despite being close to his nephew Yoshitsune, but adopted an independence stance, ruling Izumi and Kawachi Provinces (the headquarter of Kawachi-Genji branc of the Minamoto clan).

He did not take part in the campaigns by the army of Kamakura-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan to pursue and subjugate the Taira Clan, and did not visit Kamakura, despite being close to his nephew Yoshitsune, but adopted an independent stance, ruling Izumi and Kawachi Provinces (the headquarter of Kawachi-Genji branch of the Minamoto clan).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 8月、頼朝が行家討伐を計ると、行家は壇ノ浦の戦い後に頼朝と不和となっていた義経と結び、10月に反頼朝勢力を結集して後白河院から頼朝追討の院宣を受ける。
sen.e: When Yoritomo tried to subjugate Yukiie in August, he formed an ally with Yoshitsune, who was disputing with Yoritomo since the Battle of Dan no Ura, and received the order from the Goshirakawa-in (Retired Emperor Goshirakawa) to search and kill Yoritomo after rallying the anti-Yoritomo forces in October.

When Yoritomo moved to subjugate Yukiie in August, he formed an alliance with Yoshitsune, who had been in a dispute with Yoritomo since the Battle of Dan no Ura, and after rallying the anti-Yoritomo forces in October, he was ordered by Retired Emperor Goshirakawa to pursue and subjugate Yoritomo.

When Yoritomo moved to subjugate Yukiie in August, he formed an alliance with Yoshitsune, who had been in a dispute with Yoritomo since the Battle of Dan no Ura, and after rallying the anti-Yoritomo forces in October, he was ordered by Retired Emperor Goshirakawa to pursue and subjugate Yoritomo.

sen.j: しかし行家らに賛同する武士達は少なく、頼朝が鎌倉から大軍を率いて上洛する構えを見せると、11月3日、行家・義経一行は都を落ちた。
sen.e: However, there were not many bushi (samurai) who complied with Yukiie, and when Yoritomo seemed to pay a visit to Kyoto from Kamakura with his great army, Yukiie and Yoshitsune group ran away from Kyoto.

However, not many members of the warrior class were willing behind the faction led by Yukiie, and when Yoritomo made a show of force by paying a visit to Kyoto at the head of a trmendous number of troops from Kamakura, the Yukiie and Yoshitsune faction absconded from the capital.

However, not many members of the warrior class were approve of the faction led by Yukiie, and when Yoritomo made a show of force by paying a visit to Kyoto as the head of a tremendous number of troops from Kamakura, the Yukiie and Yoshitsune faction fled from the capital on November 3.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 途中大物浦で暴風雨にあって西国渡航に失敗した後は、次第に追い込まれ、逃亡の末に和泉国近木郷の神前清実の屋敷（のちの畠中城）に潜伏する。
sen.e: After encountering a strong storm at Daimotsu no Ura and failed to travel to Saigoku (western part of Japan (esp. Kyushu, but ranging as far east as Kinki)) by ship, he was gradually driven in and hid himself in the palace (later became the Hatakenaka Castle) of Kamusaki no Kiyomi in Kogigo Village, Izumi Province in the end of his escape.

After he encountered a strong storm at Daimotsu no Ura and were unable to make the voyage by ship across the inland sea to the westernmost provinces (Saigoku), he was pursued inland, and eventually hid himself in the Palace of Kamusaki no Kiyomi (subsequently Hatakenaka Castle) in Kogigo Village, Izumi Province.

After he encountered a rainstorm at Daimotsu no Ura and were unable to make the voyage by ship across the inland sea to the westernmost provinces (Saigoku), he was pursued inland, and eventually hid himself in the Palace of Kamusaki no Kiyomi (subsequently Hatakenaka Castle) in Kogigo Village, Izumi Province.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 翌年の5月、地元民の密告により露顕し、北条時定の手兵によって捕らえられ、次男源家光・三男源行頼とともに斬首された。
sen.e: He was discovered from the confession of the local civilian in May of the following year and captured by the soldier of Tokisada HOJO before being beheaded along with his second son, MINAMOTO no Iemitsu and third son, MINAMOTO no Yukiyori.

He was discovered in May of the following year, when a local resident divulged his whereabouts, and captured by soldiers of Tokisada HOJO, after which he was beheaded along with MINAMOTO no Iemitsu and MINAMOTO no Yukiyori, his second and third sons, respectively.

He was discovered in May of the following year, when a local resident divulged his whereabouts, and caught by soldiers of Tokisada HOJO, after which he was beheaded along with MINAMOTO no Iemitsu and MINAMOTO no Yukiyori, his second and third sons, respectively.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 『尊卑分脈』の記述によれば、次男・家光の子孫が5代後まで都の官人として存続しており、また四男で僧となった中納言房西乗の子・為貞は尾張国中野に居住して中野源三を称したとされる。
sen.e: According to the passage within the "Sonpi Bunmyaku," (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy), the descendants of his second son, Iemitsu, were the government official (especially one of low to medium rank) of the capital down to the fifth generation, and the fourth son who became the monk Tamesada was the child of Bo Saijo, who had the title of Chunagon (Middle Counselor) and lived in Nakano, Owari Province and called himself as Genzo NAKANO.

According to the account in the "Sonpi Bunmyaku," (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the genealogy of the aristocracy), the descendants of his second son, Iemitsu, were government officials (primarily of low to medium rank) in the capital down to the fifth generation, and a child named Tamesada born to his fourth son, who had become the monk Bo Saijo, came to hold the title of Chunagon (Middle Counselor) and lived in Nakano, Owari Province, assuming the name Genzo NAKANO.
sen.cmt: grammar, first translation of second part of sentence is unintelligible
sen.e: According to the account in the "Sonpi Bunmyaku" (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the genealogy of the aristocracy), the descendants of his second son, Iemitsu, were government officials (primarily of low to medium rank) in the capital down to the fifth generation, and a child named Tamesada born to his fourth son, who had become the monk Bo Saijo, came to hold the title of Chunagon (Middle Counselor) and lived in Nakano, Owari Province, assuming the name Genzo NAKANO.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には、織田信長の家臣として名が見える中野一安が為貞の後裔を称したほか、同じく戦国武将・新宮行朝も明確な系譜は不明であるが行家の末裔を称した。
sen.e: Kazuyasu NAKANO, who was the vassal of Nobunaga ODA during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and Yukitomo SHINGU of busho in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) claimed that they were the descendants of Yukiie but not certain for Yukitomo.

Kazuyasu NAKANO, who was a vassal of Nobunaga ODA during the Period of Warring States is said to have been a descendant of Tamesada, and it is said that Yukitomo SHINGU, who was a military commander (busho) also in the Period of Warring States, was a descendant of Yukiie, but the genealogy of Yukitomo is not clear.
sen.cmt: no mention of Tamesada in first translation, ridiculessly sloppy translation
sen.e: Kazuyasu NAKANO, who was a vassal of Nobunaga ODA during the Period of Warring States is said to have been a descendant of Tamesada, and it is said that Yukitomo SHINGU, who was a military commander (busho) also in the Period of Warring States, was a descendant of Yukiie, but the genealogy of Yukitomo is not clear.

sen.j: 愛知県蒲郡市に行家が築いたとされる五井城があった。
sen.e: There was Goi Castle in Gamagori City Aichi Prefecture that was supposedly built by Yukiie.
Goi Castle in Gamagori City, Aichi Prefecture is supposed to have been built by Yukiie.
Goi Castle in Gamagori City, Aichi Prefecture is supposed to have been built by Yukiie.

sen.j: その後、そこを居城とした松平氏が関東に移って廃城となる。
sen.e: It became an abandoned castle after Matsudaira Clan that used that castle for residence moved to Kanto (area around Tokyo).
It was abandoned after the Matsudaira Clan, which had used that castle as its residence, moved to the Kanto region (the area around Tokyo).
It was abandoned after the Matsudaira Clan, which had used that castle as its residence, moved to the Kanto region (the area around present Tokyo).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 長泉寺、真清寺の山門はこの城の門の移築で、八幡社の前の池は城の堀であるなど諸説がある。
sen.e: There are various views that main gate of Chosen-ji and Shinsen-ji Temples was the gate of this castle that was removed and rebuilt, and the pond in front of Hachiman Shrine was the moat of the castle.

There are accounts maintaining that main gate of Chosen-ji and Shinsen-ji Temples ere gates of this castle that were removed and rebuilt, and that the pond in front of Hachiman Shrine was the moat of the castle.

There are accounts maintaining that the main gates of Chosen-ji and Shinsen-ji Temples are gates of this castle that were removed and rebuilt; and that the pond in front of Hachiman Shrine was the moat of the castle.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
